_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
BC Systems is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. The Plant Engineer for the BC Systems King City site ensures that safe practices are followed in operations involving hazardous materials. This site has established emergency procedures. The BC Systems King City emergency personnel will coordinate with the local Fire Department to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP/PSM Program. The site has written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect BC Systems employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 
Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The BC Systems facility covered by this RMP is to be located at 600 Airport Road in King City, California. The facility receives produce to be processed and packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes. The produce is kept for short-term storage, transported and distributed from the site.
The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia. One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is estimated at 8,400 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. Since the amount of ammonia in the system is equal to the RMP and PSM Program threshold quantity of 8,400 pounds, the process that uses the ammonia is covered by the RMP/PSM Program requirements.
Portable Sources and Regulated Substance
There are 3 portable units stationed at this facility identified as RC3, RC4 & RC9 covered by this RMP located at 600 Airport Road in King City, California. The facility receives produce to be processed and packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes. The produce is kept for short-term storage, transported and distributed from the site.
The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia. Thr

ee portable ammonia refrigeration systems are used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge for RC3 is 3,500 pounds; RC4 contains 3,600 pounds; and RC9 contains 1,500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. Since the amount of ammonia in each portable unit is equal to the RMP and PSM Program threshold quantity of 8,900 pounds, the process that uses the ammonia is covered by the RMP/PSM Program requirements.
Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Prevention of accidental ammonia releases at BC Systems is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications prior to their occurrence, and the regular operation, maintenance and monitoring of the system. This includes:
A?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction of the system, as well as in the event of system modifications through a management of change process.
A?    Performance of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least once every five years using accurate process safety information.
A?    Implementation of operating, maintenance and monitoring procedures. 
A?    Training of system operations and maintenance personnel, as well as ongoing training of the on-site Chemical Response Team. 
A?    Performances of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to hot work permit program requirements to ensure mechanical integrity.
A?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols.
A?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system.
The detailed Prevention Program for this system is contained in a supporting document, which is to be maintained at by the site by the Plant Engineer.
Five Year Accident History
This is a new installation of an ammonia refrigeration system. Therefore, no ammonia releases resulting in on-site or off-site injuries,

deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred. 
Emergency Response Program
This facility has established emergency procedures and coordinates with the local Fire Department to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP/PSM Program. 
The Emergency Response procedures are accessible at the site, and copies are maintained in the King City Plant Engineer's files. The document describes response procedures for various emergency scenarios, including the mitigation of hazardous material releases, agency notification procedures in the event of a hazardous material release, and emergency equipment available at the site. 
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Based on the process hazard analysis studies conducted for the system, which are contained in a separate document, the following consolidated list of actions were identified to ensure safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.
